raw_response: {"answer_index": 2, "answer_text": "HSV-1", "confidence": 10, "reasoning": "This is a classic presentation of primary herpetic gingivostomatitis, most commonly caused by HSV-1. Key features include: 5-year-old child (typical age for primary infection), painful vesicular lesions on oral mucosa/lips/gingiva, fever (39.1°C), odynophagia preventing oral intake, cervical/submandibular lymphadenopathy, and systemic symptoms (myalgias, irritability). Primary HSV-1 infection typically presents more severely than recurrent episodes. CMV would be unusual in an immunocompetent child and presents differently. HIV doesn't cause acute vesicular oral lesions. HSV-2 primarily causes genital lesions and is rare in oral cavity, especially in children.", "evidence_quality": "normal"}
